details.title: Reliability inferences of modulated power-law process #i

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Stat., Bhavnagar Univ., India

p: K. Muralidharan received the M.Sc. degree (1987) in statistics from Calicut University, Kerala, and the M.Phil. (1992) and Ph.D. (1997) degrees in statistics from Sardar Patel University, Vallabh Vidhyanagar.

He is a Reader (Assistant Professor) with the Department of Statistics, Bhavnagar University, Bhavnagar. He has been heading the department since 1996. Prior to this appointment he was a Lecturer in Statistics in M.S. University of Baroda from 1990 to 1996. Dr. Muralidharan is working on a collaborative research project with Prof. B. K. Kale of the Department of Statistics, University of Pune, Pune. His research interests includes statistical inference, testing of hypothesis, reliability theory, mixture distributions, and Bayes estimation. He has more than 22 publications in national and international journals, and is a statistical consultant with several companies in Bhavnagar.

authors.name: K. Muralidharan

details.abstract: The PLP (power-law process) is often used to model failure data from repairable systems, when both renewal type behavior and time trends are present. This paper considers the reliability inferences of modulated-PLP models. The maximum likelihood estimate and the uniformly minimum variance unbiased estimate of Modulated PLP #i are derived and computed numerically. Two examples are given.

references.title: Repairable System Reliability: Modeling and Their Causes

context.text: The NHPP and RP are commonly used models to describe the failure pattern of repairable systems [1].

references.text: H. Ascher, H. Feingold, Repairable System Reliability: Modeling and Their Causes, 1984, Marcel Dekker.

references.title: Inhomogeneous and modulated gamma process

context.text: References [2] and [5] propose point-process models, which incorporate both renewal type behavior and time trends with application to repairable systems.

references.text: M. Berman, "Inhomogeneous and modulated gamma process", Biometrica, vol. 68, pp. 143-152, 1981.

references.title: Bayes inference for the modulated power law process

context.text: Reference [3] proposes a Bayes analysis of the parameters of MPLP with unknown scale and shape parameters; this is not treated in this paper.

references.text: R. Calabria, G. Pulcini, "Bayes inference for the modulated power law process", Comm. Statist.̵Theory and Methods, vol. 26, no. 10, pp. 2421-2438, 1997.

references.title: The modulated power law process

context.text: The MPLP [4] is a compromise between the RP and the NHPP with power intensity function often referred to as PLP, because its failure probability at a given time \$t\$ depends on the age \$t\$ of the system and on the distance of \$t\$ from the latest failure time.
Reference [4] also discusses the ML and point estimates of the three parameters of the MPLP models.

references.text: M. J. Lakey, S. E. Rigdon, "The modulated power law process", Proc. 45th Ann. Quality Congress, pp. 559-563, 1992.

references.title: A point-process model incorporating renewals and time trends with application to repairable systems

context.text: References [2] and [5] propose point-process models, which incorporate both renewal type behavior and time trends with application to repairable systems.

references.text: J. F. Lawless, K. Thiagarajah, "A point-process model incorporating renewals and time trends with application to repairable systems", Technometrics, vol. 38, no. 2, pp. 131-138, 1996.

references.title: On testing of parameters in modulated power law process
references.text: K. Muralidharan, "On testing of parameters in modulated power law process", Applied Stochastic Models in Business and Industry, Mar. 2002.

references.title: Theoretical explanation of observed decreasing failure rate

context.text: To illustrate this method, consider the failure data from the second aircraft air-conditioning unit [7] with \$n=21\$ failures, as presented in Table IV.

references.text: F. Proschan, "Theoretical explanation of observed decreasing failure rate", Technometrics, vol. 5, pp. 375-383, 1963.

references.title: Learning curve approach to reliability

context.text: Example 2 consists of the failure times of an aircraft generator [8] for \$n=14\$ failures [9].

links.abstract: Several different and complex electromechanical and mechanical systems are shown to have remarkably similar rates of reliability improvement during system development. These similarities provide the basis for a learning curve which can be used to monitor development progress, predict growth patterns, and plan programs for reliability improvement.

references.text: J. T. Duane, "Learning curve approach to reliability", IEEE Trans. Aerospace, vol. 2, pp. 563-566, 1964.

references.title: Statistical inference for a modulated power law process

context.text: Example 2 consists of the failure times of an aircraft generator [8] for \$n=14\$ failures [9].

references.text: S. E. Black, S. E. Rigdon, "Statistical inference for a modulated power law process", J. Quality Technol., vol. 28, no. 1, pp. 81-90, 1996.

nonIeee.title: Reliability analysis of repairable systems using stochastic point processes
nonIeee.displayText: Fu-rong Tan, Zhi-bin Jiang, Tong-shuo Bai, "Reliability analysis of repairable systems using stochastic point processes", Journal of Shanghai Jiaotong University (Science), vol. 13, pp. 366, 2008, ISSN 1007-1172.

nonIeee.title: ANOTHER LOOK AT NONPARAMETRIC ESTIMATION FOR TREND RENEWAL PROCESSES
nonIeee.displayText: Yasuhiro Saito, Tadashi Dohi, "ANOTHER LOOK AT NONPARAMETRIC ESTIMATION FOR TREND RENEWAL PROCESSES", Journal of the Operations Research Society of Japan, vol. 59, pp. 312, 2016, ISSN 0453-4514.

nonIeee.displayText: Olivier Gaudoin, Bo Yang, Min Xie, "Confidence Intervals for the Scale Parameter of the Power-Law Process", Communications in Statistics - Theory and Methods, vol. 35, pp. 1525, 2006, ISSN 0361-0926.
